MONDAY, MARCH 27, 1905.

div.head: A WORD OF WARNING.
div.p: Our columns contained on Saturday last two articles side by side, between which at first sight there is little connection, but which, nevertheless, bear one upon the other in u way that does not appear on the surface. One was headed “Egypt’s Mines: a Boom in London,” the other "Lord and Lady Cromer, an interesting sketch.” It is to one paragraph in each article that we wish to call our readers’ attention. Egyptian gold mining has of late attracted much attention, and it is while it is as yet in its. infancy, — we had almost written its second infancy, but that term is significant of dotage rather than a renewal of activity—that decisions must be formed, and steps taken to ensure that in the future there shall be no trouble in consequence of the overlooking of due precautions in the initial stages of development of the gold i mines. In the article to which we refer, and which appeared in the “Financier,” we find the following :—

“There is ono point which should not be overlooked just as Egyptians are entering upon a phase of activity that will last just as long as the market is maintained in a healthy condition, and that is the question of labour. This not a burning question, nor happily can it ever be made a party ques- tion, as in the case of the Rand. But in these vast areas of the Upper Nile the population is exceedingly sparse, and consequently labourers are few. In the near future labour will have to be imported, hut this can he done easily from India, the coolies there finding congenial surroundings in the valley of the Nile. The point does not arise imme- diately because the mines are only in the development stage, but it will later, and it is as well to realise the fact now instead of ever allowing it to become a market factor, and ultimately a paralysing mining one.” We will put this into other words, and see how well it fits in with the extract from the other article, which runs as follows "Our prosperity is as true as the sunshine, without clouds of rain ; many millions are waiting to be used. This is the testing point in the history of Egypt It wants the iron hand in the velvet glove to keep down the incoming stream of h peculate re, some honest bringing progress and advancement, some driven by that hell-fire, the gamblers’ in- stinct, and the last dishonest, ready to sacrifice anybody and anything to get hold of the alluring millions.”

The meaning of this is dear and precise. Let ns proceed to read into it the true significance of the other, bearing in mind what had been said before in the same article:—Never mind the cold douche which Lord Cromer once administered and which bid fair to give Egyptian mining it quietus ; in Egypt and the Sudan lies enormous wealth in the way of ancient gold mines and newly- discovered gold areas, to which the wealth of the Rand is as nothing. Get your foothold there. Never mind the Egyptian nation to whom the wealth rightly belongs. Secure the land, and secure the right to import cheap foreign labour, so that foreign capital may have for its working machinery a class of labour that will not have any interest other than those of the people who employ them. We might add a good deal more that may notbe implied by the writer, but would most cer- tainly result, from the importation of Indian coolies into Egypt and the Sudan, it behoves the authorities to use the utmost vigilance in this matter so as to make it impossible for any future British Agent to sanction such a pro- ceeding. Prevention is better than cure, and forewarned is forearmed. One of the most ex- perienced mining engineers of the day to whom we referred the question—we mean Mr. Alford —told ns that the proposal to employ coolie labour was a perfectly practical ore, com- mercially speaking, whatever it might be politically. We think it oar duty to make the most emphatic protest in our power against the proposal being even considered possible to be entertained, either now, five, ten, or twenty years hence, or during the existence of any lease or concession that may be granted. We have not the slightest wish to discou- rage the development of the mining industry in Egypt, on the contrary we foresee a great future for it. If, as seems possible, land development may undergo somewhat of a check through the Assouan dam decision, it may well be that capitalists will turn their at- tention to the mineral wealth of the country, and there is something very fascinating in the thought of the old workings being re- opened, and the almost fabulous wealth of ancient times again obtained. But our desire is to see this wealth distributed. over as large an area as possible and to prevent its going into the hands of the men who are... “dishonest, ready to sacri- fice anybody and anything to get hold of the alluring millions.” Lord Cromer possesses the iron hand in the velvet glove, and, ail the “Finaucier” writer admits, has used it in the past with effect. His work in Egypt is not as yet within measurable distance of being ac- complished, and the phenomenal prosperity of the present times only places fresh burdens on his shoulders, in place of those of which the smooth currents of late years have in some measure relieved him. We would call upon all to give him most hearty and generous support, and if in the true interests of Egypt Lord Cromer has to make a firm stand against importunate capitalists, eager for their own interests only, and careless of the well-being of the people, as so many of these prove them- selves, we trust that it will never be a reproach to the British community resident in Egypt, that at any critical moment that may come, they failed to give his lordship the strong backing he has every right to expect from them.

THE EXPANSION OF CAIRO- The petition that has been sent in to the Government by the residents and proprietors of Boulac-avenue will, it is to be hoped, meet with the attention it deserves, for it is not only a fair statement of the interests of the petitioners but also of those of the entire community. As we pointed out some, little time ago when dealing with the ques- tion of house accommodation in Cairo, one of the really pressing questions of the day is the facilitating of the expansion that the city is now undergoing. More and more every day the residents within what were formerly the limits of the town are being pushed outwards from the centre to make way for the steadily growing need of ampler accommodation for the purely commercial and business demands on the available house and building space. The results of the difficulties arising from the pre- sent condition of affairs are highly injurious to all the best interests of the town and of the community, and the one real, and indeed only, effective remedy that can be applied is the opening up of the vacant spaces lying within a three or four-mile radius from the centre of the city. That this may be done it is essential that the Nile may be so bridged that it may cease to be the formidable barrier it now is to the natural growth of the town. The existing bridge is situated in perhaps the wont possible site that could be chosen for this purpose, and that upon which work has already been commenced at, or rather just beyond, Foum el Khalig, though it will meet a very important demand and will have a very great effect upon the expansion of Ghizeh, will do but little for Cairo itself except indirectly, by in some degree relieving the pressure upon its residential accommodation. The bridge advocated by the petition to which we have referred would, however, do infinitely more, and if accompanied by the provision of a tramway service at this point, would unques- tionably do more to meet existing difficulties than any other measure that can be proposed.

div.head: THE WAR
div.p: ANOTHER JAPANESE ADVANCE
LINDEVITCH TO PURSUE FABIAN TACTICS
Gutzuling, March 28
General Lindevitch is taking measures to cope with the Japanese turning movement.(Havas)
Gutzuling,March 28
The Japanese are again advancing. They caused the Russian reargaurd to retreat 13 miles to xxx, which is 40 miles to the south of Gutzuling.(Reuter)
St. Petersburg, March 28.

It is uderstood that the intention to mobilize on a large scale has been abndoned for the present. Only drafts of sufficient strength to stiffen Linievitch's army will be sent. Te General will pursue Fabian tactics. (Reuter)

div.head: THE JAPANESE LOAN
div.p: SCENES IN LONDON
New York, MArch 28
The bankers state they are receiving many French subscriptions for the American version of the Japanese loan.(Reuter)
London,March 28

The exterior of the bamks which are issuing the Japanese loan resembles Boxing Day at the theatres. Special police are preserving order. There are long queues of persons outside the banks, the largest being around the Hong Kong and Shanghai office. It is certain that the loan will be heavily oversubscribed.(R)

div.head: ANGLO-JAPANESE ALLIANCE
div.p: London, March 28

The "Daily Telegraph", in taking up the idea of strengthening the alliance between Britain and Japan, says that the suggetion is receiving general approbation in the City. This will especially be the case if the idea enjoys the moral support of America.(Reuter)

div.head: FINLAND
div.p: SYSTEMATIC CONSTITUTIONAL AGITITATION
Helsingfors, March 28.

A systematic constitutional agitation has begun in Finland and is spreading considerably. A demonstration at Abo was attended by 20,000 persons. Crowds are parading the streets waving revolutionary flags; bands are playing national airs.(Reuter)

div.head: THE RISING IN CRETE
div.p: Suda,March 28
H.M. cruiser "Lancaster" has arrived here.(Reuter)

div.head: CHURCH AND STATE IN FRANCE
div.p: Paris, March 28
Five Cardinals have sent M.Loubet a protest in favor of the Concordat.(Havas)

div.head: NEW ITALIAN CABINET
div.p: Rome, March 28
The Cabinet has been formed with Signor xxxx as President and Signor Tittoni as minister for Foreign Affairs.(Havas)

div.head: RACING
div.p: LINCOLNSHIRE HANDICAP
London, March 28

1.Sansovino; 2.Catty Crag; 3.Ranger II. 18 ran. Won by a head,neck dividing second and third. Starting Price Betting: 100 to 9 against Sansovino, 11 to 2 against Catty Cray, and 25 to 2 against Ranger II. (R)

div.head: THE TROUBLES OF RUSSIA
div.p: THE CRIMEAN DISTURBANCES
VIOLEN OUTBREAKS IN CAUCASUS
Yalta(Crimea),March 28

The disturbances begn here on Sunday evening when the town was ignited in five places. The crowd obstructed the work of extinguishing the themes. All the police stations were wrecked and the prisoners liberated the attempt to sack the municipal treasury wa frustrated. (Reuter)
St Petersburg, March 28

Violent outbreaks are occuring in many parts of the Caucasus both in the town and country. The peasants declare that they can only obtain concessions by force, and they are, therefore, attacking the municipal buildings and the country seats of the nobles. The Government is sending troops into the district. There is a marked recrudescence of unrest throughout Russia, apparently in pursuance of a "mot d'ordre." (Reuter)
Yalta, MArch 28
Warships and military reinforcements have arrived here. Order has been restored(R)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Brindisi Mail will be distributed at the GPO, Alexandria, at 6:30 pm today. The French Ball at Cairo on the 24th ulto. has yielded from 38,000 to 40,000 francs. An Assault at Ams will e given in hte Sulle d'Escrime in the Esbekich Gardens on Saturday next. Ministry of Justice- The report of the Judicial Adviser will be presented t the Council of Ministries before the end of the month. The Reunion Des Families Society are giving their last ball of the winter season on Saturday next, April 1. Masks and costumes will be worn. PWD-Mr. AH Perry, Director-General of towns and Buildings, has completed his annual report, which is to be submitted shortly to Sir Wm. Garstin. Aldersons Garden.- On and from Saturday, 8th April, the variety entertainment in Aldersons Garden Theatre will take place every SAturday at 5pm instead of Fridays. A Ball will be given in Saturday net at the "Club des Princes", Cairo, under the patronage of Miss Gennadis, on behalf of the Greek language propoganda in Thace. Viennese Choral Society.- The members of this society gave a concert at Abdeen Paalace on Monday evening. Yesterday they made an excursion to Sakkara and are gving a concert in Shepheard's Hotel garden this evening. Egyptian Investment- The London Stock Exchange Committee has ordered the undermentioned security to be quoted in the Offiial List:- Egyptian Investment and Agency, 200,000 shares of 1 each, 5s, paid, Nos.1 to 200,000. Suez Canal.- On the 25th and 26th inst. 34 vessels passed through the Canal, the receipts for the two days being frs. 815,022,84. 15 of the ships were British, 2 Italian, 9 Russian, 3 Greek, 5 German. The total receipts from the 1st inst. amounted to frs. 9,087,41299. ALM&DS- At the Sailors and Soldiers' Institute last night, a lecture was given under the auspices of the above society b the Rev. Reginald Rynd, BA, on the "The Natural Use of the Voice". A ggrsat deal of valuable information was conveyed by the lecturer as to the proper mode of developing the vocal organs, and his description of the various reasonant organs of the human frame- in themselves very lucidly described-was rendered still more plain by a large diagram of the head and throat, The importance of the proper management of the resonant organs, nd the way in whic to best avoid the hindrances to good singing, presented by the tongue, throatiness, etc., were fully set forth, and at the close of the lecture the appreciation of the audiece as plainly expressed. A vote of thanks to the reverend lectuer was proposed by Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, KCMG, who presided, and was heartily accorded. We hope that Mr.Rynd wll favor he society with many more of these interesting contributons to the proper understanding of music, nothwithstanding the discouragingly small number of members who turned up last night.

div.head: TERRIBLE ACCIDENT
div.p: THREE MEN BURIED ALIVE

A terrible accident occurred at Alexandria yesterday afternoon about 5 o'clock, by which three men lost their lives. In Stamboul street, just behind Groppi's establishment, building operations are proceeding, and at the time mentioned the foundations of the house being built gave way, burying three native masons in the debris. Towards evening, the dead bodies of two of the men were recovered, while the other remained buried under a mass of earth and stone. From investigations which we have made, it appears that at a depth of four metres these men were engaged in building up the earth i nthe form of an arch. Th carelessness of native workmen is notorious. It seems that in forming the arch they had taken away some earth on the side of the escarpment. This weakened the layer of earth on top and caused the landslip. Under the circumstances the blame for the unfortunate accident must fall on the victims themselves, as no one but they can tell the stability of their position. Had they been simple workmen, the responsibility would lie with the employers, who should have capable overseers.
AL AZHAR UNIVERSITY

The third uhma of the Al Ahzar University, Sheikh Ahmed el Hanbali, has resigned his seat in the council of directors of the University. Two sheikhs only remain, Sheikh Hassanein El Boulaki and Sheikh Hassanein El Edoui. We hear on good authority that candidates for cadi hip will near future, after passing an examination at Al Azhar at an early period of their studies there, go through a special course of training which will be entirely independent of the ancient university
UPPER EGYPT HOTELS COMPANY

Referring to the announcement which appeared in our columns yesterday, we are informed that the Savoy Hotel, Assouan, will not now be included in the above company, as stated, owing to the fact that the necessary arrangements have not been concluded with the Anglo-American Company. The capital of the new company is 220,000, in shares of 4 each, snd 100,000 in 5% first mortgage debentures. The directors will be Mr. AE Harrison, general manager of Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son, (Egypt), Ltd, George Nungovich Bey, Mr. Charles Baehler, and Mr. Pagnon.
STATE OPERA

We hear that a petition is circulating among the abonnes of the Khedival Opera House (and obtaining numerous signatures), copies of which will be addressed to the Minister of Public Works and to Lord Cromer, Mr Vincent Corbett and Sir William Gastin. The petitiondeals with the decision of the Socitete Artistique to bring an Italian company over in the season 1905-1906, in spite of the decision taken some time ago, and aproved by the Government, to bring French companies over in alternate years. The signatories of the petition complain of this breach of the regulations pointing out that the arrangement previously made enabled good new operas (which by the concession must be produced to the number of four a year) to be brought before the Cairo public. They disclaim all nationalist bias and assert that the plea of the societe Artistique, viz, that a good French company cannot be procured, is utterly untenable. They therefore beg the Minister of Public Works to intervene on behalf of the Government and the public. In our opinion the best way out of the difficulty would be to revoke the concession as soon as possible, and hand over the entire business to a good impressario.. The proverb "Too many cooks" is alarmingly true in Egypt.
CAIRO ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS

Many additions have been made to the menagerie in these gsrdens during the last two months, and one of the prettiest sights now to be seen near Cairo is that of the young gazelles and ibex, of which more than a dozen have recently been born at Ghizeh, playing and frisking about with their mothers in the large paddock which occupies the site of the ruins of the old palace. The births thi spring also include an Arui wild sheep and two Hedjaz sheep, and among the birds, besides numerosu doves of various kinds, two buff-backed egrets have been hatched and reared. Seventeen animals have been presented: an Egyptian weasel by Mrs. Colville, a hawk-eagle by Mr. H. Raczinski of Alexandria, a Nilotic waran-lizard from Luxor by Prof. Dr. G. Schweinfurth, a ring-necked parakeet by Mrs.Bazil, three slender lorises by Mr. J.A. Tarrell, a jungle cat by Mr.AE Branch, seven trumpeter bullfinches and a spotted cuckoo by Mr. GH Malcolm, an a greyheaded love-bird by Mr. S. Hanauer. The purchases during the same period include a yellow baboon, avery larg bonnet-monkey, a white nosed red monkey, some lemurs, two species of wild cat, a Loder's gazelle from the Fayoum, a mouse deer from India, several pretty species of birds not previously represented in the collection, as the lavender finch of Tropical Africa and the Pein nightingale, also two Mina birds, and finally an Algerian tortoise.
By the kind permission of the Inspector General of Prisons, the band of the Ghieh Boys' School will play on Friday afternoons in the gardens throughout this year.

div.head: THE SIRDAR AT SUAKIN
div.p: RECEPTOON BY INHABITANTS
(from our Correspondent)
Suakin, March 16

During his recent visit to Suakin, the Sirdar distributed several robes and other valuable gifts, such as medal dresses, watches, revolvers, knives, and shaving articles, to a large number of sheikhs of tribes, clergy, and faithful guides and attenants for their loyal services these few years to the Government. After this ceremony was over he delivered an eloquent address in English which lasted 45 minutes, and which was then interpreted into Arabic by his Arabic secretar, Shaheen Bey, and afterwards again interpreted into Hadendow by the Commandant of Police, Mohamed Bey Ahmed.

In the evening his Excellency was entertained at dinner at the Moudirieh. Afterwards a reception was held, when Saghcolaghassi Aly Effendy Ahmed,Deputy-Inspector of Suakin Moudirieh, addressed his excellency the Sirdar in English as follows: "Your Excellency,-I have been chosen by the Egyptian officers, officials and employes of the Government of Suakin to stand respectfully before your Excellency and to express their happiness on your visit to this province and town. All the people of whatever station, the richest and the poorest, the highest and the lowest, have taken this oppurtunity to welcome you by their shouts and respond to the consideration and goodwill you have ever shown to all. All whom you find around you are anxious to assure you of their warm feelings and pleasure. The whole Sudan recognises and is grateful for the wise and good administration of the coutnry. The whole Sudan recognises and is ggrateful for the manner in which the happiness and well-being of all classes are considered. Not only the whole Sudan, but the whole world recognises the spledid way in which the country has thriven during the years which you have been Sirdar and Governor General of the Sudan, and wonders at the magnificent manner in which the resources of the coutnry are being developed. It is true that during this period all departments of the GOvernment have accomplished much, but in this province we watch perhaps more keenly than others, the miles of railway which are joining the Nile and Red Sea, and the plans for the development of the ports of the Sudan. We know that all that has been the result of your master spirit and encouragement. I am not able to express all that is on my mind, but specially we would thank your Excellency for the honor of your visit to us this evening, and in this way showing that you have a warm heart and kind feelings for all those serving the Government of this country. I ask all who are present to drink the health of his Excellency the Sirdar of the Egyptian Army and the Governor-General of the Sudan, El Ferik Sir Francis Reginald Wingate Pasha." The following congratulatory order was published after the Sirdar's departure:-El Miralai Howard Bey, Mr. Kerr, and the military officers and officials of the Egyptian Army and Sudan Government for their admirable arrangements for his recetion, and for their good and hard work to which the very marked improvement in the condition and progress of the town and province since his last inspection in 1901 is due. "He was much struck with the smartness and turn out of the guard of honor furnished by the 3rd Battalion, and the excelence of the organisation and the careful arrangements made for the treatment of the sick in the military and civil hospitals. The interest taken in education as evinced by the satisfactory state of the school and scholars, was most marked. He also wishes you to convey to El Miralai Macauley Bey his great appreciation of the hard and valuable work done by him and his staff on the new Railway, of which the substantial progress already made is the best testimony. In conclusion he would like to express to you, your officers and officials, and to all classes of people of Suakin, his cordial thanks for the loyal and hearty reception on his arrival and hospitatlity extended to him during his stay." (Signed): LO Stack, Kaimakam, Mil. and Private Secretary.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY
div.p: The following officers have been promoted to the rank of Miralai:- Kaimakams H Matchett Bey, L. Stanton Bey, R Griffith Bay, W Persse Bey, C Blunt Bey, R. Griffith Bey, G. Maucalay Bey, and L Satck Bey. Miralai GP Hunter Bey, DSO., has been appointed Principal Medical Officer of the Egyptian Army.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner "Tabor" arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning. The SS "Grecian Prince", from Manchester, left Malta on Monday and is due here on Friday next, with passengers and general cargo. The SS Crypian Prince, from Antwerp, left London on Monday last, with passengers and general cargo for Malta and Alexandria.
CANON DAVIS MEMORIAL
DEDICATION SERVICE

The short service held by the Bishop in Jerusalem and the East at 4:45pm on Monday in St. Mark's Church was quite private. It had not been possible to fix the exact hour until the day before, too late t announce it in the "Gazette". The Bishop, who was attended by his acting chaplain, the Rev. Canon Ward, inserted the following special prayers in a shortened form of evening service. "In the faith of Jesus Christ we dedicate this memorial stone, now handed over to the charge of the chaplain and the trustees of St. Marks Church, to the peretual memory of the Csnon Edwin John Davis, MA i nthe church in which he s long ministered. May those who worship here, and face his effigy as they go out from this House of God into the world, hear in memory the example of one of whose loving and charitable labours for the good of Christ's poor, should stimulate the spirit of charity in others; and whose watchful care of the interests of this foundation of St. Mark's has left to his successors great possibilities for happy influence in the chaplaincy which he served for so long a time. "Assist us mercifully, O Lord, in these our supplications and prayers, and in this our act of thy servants towards the attainment of everlasting salvation, that among all the changes and chances of this mortal life we may ever be defended by Thy most gracious and ready help; through Jesus Christ our Lord. Amen"
PROVINCIAL CHURCH SERVICES
TANTAH
MANSOURAH

At Mansourah the services will be as follows:- April 2, evensong, 6pm; April 9, Litany and HC, 11 am; April 16, evensong, 6pm. Note- Collections on the last Sunday at both chuches (1st after Easter) will be devoted to the SPG. All other offertories and collectioms go to the Delta Itinerating Chaplaincy Fund. J. David C. Firminger, SPG Chaplain
LA DELEGATION MUNICIPALE

La Delegation Municipale s'est reunie le 28 mars 1905 a 4h. pm sous la presidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli. La Delegation arrete parmi le programme des routes a faire cette annee. Les devis at cahier des charges devront etre presentes au fur et a mesure au College pour la mise en adjucation. Elle adjuge a M. Degiarde la furniture de 60 bancs et 40 chaises pour le jardin Nousha; la route de Ramleh, a M Erriques; enfin la fourniture de balais et couffins, a MM Abdel Rahim Hekel et a M Stamatepoulo. Les offres presentes pour la demolition d'une maison, rue Sinadino, n'ayant pas para satisfaisantes, la Delegation decide de refaire une nouvelle adjucation pour ce travail. La Delegation renvoie au sujet de la construction de la conduite de raccordement pour le deversement des eaux de lavage des nouveaux filtres. Elle proposera a la Commission l'overture d'un credit supplementaire de LE 600 pour le jardin Nouzhe. La seance est le ee a 8h. pm.
CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
THEATRE ZIZINIA
NOTRE JEUNESSE

Avec la representation de Notre Jeunesse, la compagnie Coquelin Cadet a pu enregistrar une de see crations, et M. Jean Coquelin s'y est autant distingue dans le role de Lucien Briant qu'avanthier dans celui du marquis de La Seigliere Quant a Mme Moreno, elle a su rendre a la perfection deux ou trois soenes pathetiques qui lui ont valune ovation. Nous devons encore une mention particuliere a Mme Bouchetal et a l'heureuse interprete du role de Luoienne Briant qui ont ete toutes deux justement remarquees. M. Coquelin Cadet a termine la representation par trois monologues qu'il a debite d'uue facon exquise. Ce soir Lee Romanesques, comedie en trois actes de M. Edmond Rostand, et L'Ete de la Sanit Martin, comedie en un acte de MM. Meilhac et Halevy.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Major General Sir Ronald Lane and Lieutenant General Sir Thomas Kelly Kenny, who have respectively held the positions of Military Secretary and Adjucant General to the British Army, are leaving Egypt on Monday next by the Bibby SS Staffordshire from Port Said Sir Ronald Line is staying with Mr. Gould until tomorrow when he returns for a few days to Cairo.
Yesterday Sir Ronald paid a visit to Victoria College in company with Mr. Gould and was very much pleased with this institution.

The "Journal du Cairo" remarks:- On donne comme probable la nomination de M. Sheldon Amos, juge au Tribunal indigene de re instance du Caire, comme conseiller a la Cour d'appel indigene en remplacement de M. Coghlan.
The Italian man of war "Liguria" is expected to arrive at Alexandria shortly with the Duke of the Abruzzi, who is on his way home after a voyage round the world.

It is not generally known that the credit for the suggestion of England's purchase of the "St. James Gazette", whose 75th birthday is to be celebrated by a banquet in London. When an oppurtunity offered of buying the Suez Canal shares which now form so important a national asset, it was Mr. Greenwood who suggested the purchase to Disareli. Disareli jumped at it, and the thing was done. The statesman got the kudos, but to the journalist belongs the credit.

Egypt has been from the beginning the background for a career of much distinction in the case of Captain Colin Keppel, who has been recently appointed to succeed Sir A Milne in command of His Majesty's yachts. During the attempt to relieve General Gordon, in the subsequent rescue of Sir C. Wilson under Lord Charles Beresford, on the Nile in 1898, when he commanded the flotilla, and at the CB, Captain Keppel won unqualified praise for his ability and courage. As a midshipman be participated in the bombbardment of Alexandria.
Mr JIR Dempster, whose sudden death we annonced yesterday, was chief engineer of the New Egyptian Compsnys Nile reclamation works.
Mr.ALP Weigall has been appointed inspector to the Antiques Service at an annual salary of LE 400.
The Rev. Alf. A. Cooper, MA, of the British and Foreign Bible Society, is expected back in Alexandria on the 1st prox. Mr. Cooper travels by way of Berlin, Vienna, and Constantinople.

The following officers have been granted leave of absence on private affairs:- Capt. S.J.Somerville and 2nd Lieut.CEG Varnon, 2nd Royal Inniskiling Fusiliers; Liet Col. Berks. Regt., Capt.GB Byrne and 2nd Lieut RSW Walpole, 2nd Rifle Brigade; Liet. TC Cunningham, AOD. Major EJ Lawson, AVD.

div.head: NOTES FROM ASSIOUT
div.p: ARRIVAL OF NEW MOUDIR
Assiout, March 24
Our new Moudir, Hassan Bey Wassif, arrived
here here two days ago and was warmly welcomed
by the people. Assoiut expects a great deal
of from him. He is distinguished among the
mondirs the provinces for his intelligence and
experience, which we hope he will use for the
benefit of our moudirieh.

div.head: THREE DEATH SENTENCES IN 20 DAYS.
div.p: The Court of Assiout has delivered three
Death sentences since the beginning of March.
The first was the case of a young man of about
22 years of age, who murdered his father in
order to inherit on and a half feddans of land
which the latter possessed.
The second was the case of a certain Awad
Said Bekbit of Awlad-cl-Sheik (Ghirgeh) who
murdered three persons in one minute. This man
intended to murder the emdeh of his village,
because the latter had accused him of crimes
the perpetrators of which were unknown.
Accordingly, he went with his rifle to the house
of the omdeb, in the month of August 1903,
with the intention of shooting him. Arrived
there he fired but missed the omeh. The
shot, however, took effect on two men who
were sitting near by, killing them on the spot.
The criminal fired again at the omdeh and
a third man was killed by the second shot.
The prisoner confessed his crime and was
condemned to death.
The third case occurred at Mellawi Station.
Two months ago a certain Mustapha Abdul
Ghani was shot there, and on equiries being
Institied the murder confessed, and named
a merchant of the place as being his associate.
The latter was condemmed to death, as
it was proved that he had played the most important
part in the commission of the crime.
It is unual to have three judegments
of dead passed in three weeks in a single
court. But crime is increasing every day,
and it would occupy a great deal of space
daily to tell of the crime in Assiout alone.
There must be something wrong in the
machinery of the police; and that this is
the case will be proved in my next letter.

div.head: PORT SAID AND AFTER
div.p: (Eva Anstruther, in the “Westminister Gazette.”)
…Lit each by one red glowing eye of flame,
the low coal barges cluster round the ship.
And, through the night, a dark-hued human
chain,
Coal-laden, chanting, hoarsely, noisily,
Like black invading demons climb the planks,
From barge to ship, and back to barge again,
Casting their burden in the vessel’s hold.
Then, with the dawn, the ship’s heart throbe
anew,
And, leaving in her wake busy port,
She glides into the narrow water-way
That, like a blade of finely-tempered steel,
Pierces the desert’s heart, from sea to sea.
On either side the land, arid and pale,
Stretched afar, in the still monotony;
Unbroken, save where shadows of the clouds
Lie faintly purple on the barren and…
RUSSIA TO-DAY.
TO THE EDITOR of the "Egptian Gazette ”
Sir,—The letter in your issue of yesterday is an excellent demonstration of the truth of the old saying that certain folks rush in where angels fear to tread.

If the writer of the article in question knew anything of the subject, even to the extent of the little knowledge which is a dangerous tiling, he would be aware that the position of the Russian Army to-day and that of the Federals after the Battle of Rappahannock are as different as light is from darkness.
The Federals were defeated, it is true, but they were near their bases, and did not depend
For the supply of ammunitions and provisons on
the limited carrying power of about for thousands
miles of single line railway, with a disloyal personnel.

The writer has been directly concerned in a responsible way with the commissariat of a force of 20,000 fighting men, at a distance of less than 1,000 miles from their base, and be knows how many anxious days and sleepless nights were passed in order to keep the kettles boiling.

That Russian can raise another 500,000 men nobody doubts, but that she can ever transport them to the seat of the war, or deed them even if they were once there, is as impossible as to teach a horse to live on sawdust.
The reference to the Anglo-Boer War shows as much ignorance of military matters as the remarks on Rappahannock.
True it is that the British were far from their base, by the seas was an open highway, and we could send down any number of men we could recruit, and limitless supplies of munitions and provisions.
Against us was an army of say 80,000 men, which included every fighting man of the whole populations, and when that force was worn out, there was no hope replacing it.
But with Japan it is otherwise. Her population is sufficient to enable her to keep up her present armaments and her financial credit such that she need fear no lack of the sinews of war.
The present position of affairs is a striking proof of the verity of the verse of Cowper’s hymn quoted by your correspondent.
Truly God moves in a mysterious way. His arm has struck down the ruthless assassins of His people.
“Our God hath crushed the tyrant
Our God hath raised the slave;
Hath mocked the counsel of the wise,
The valour of the brave.
Then glory to His holy Name”
From whom all glories are,
And glory to the little Japs
Who chased the Russians far.
I trust he great historian will forgive me, if ghost can forgive, for the termination I have to put to his lines.
At the risk of being considered naughty, I mist quote a verse on which name into my head on reading the conclusion of Mr. Atwood’s letter:
“He moves in a mysterious way To drive Oyama forth.
He never budges towards the south. But always towards the north.
I am, etc.,
Henry C.SIMS
Cairo, March 25.
HAVE YOU THESE SYMPTOMS?
Diseased Kidneys Cause Backache, Urinary Disorders, Gravel, Dizziness, Puffy Flesh, Nervousness, and Irregular Heart's Action.
Kidney disease does not usually come on with sharp pain. If it did it would not be so dangerous, because the patient would at once seek treatment and relief.
On the contrary, most often it comes on quietly — may have been working in the system for years before the patient suspected the real cause of his trouble.
There may have been backaches, limbaches, neuralgia, sciatica, rheumatism, a nervous, irritable feeling, or a generally tired feeling, weak heart, dropsy, etc.
He did not know these were symptoms of kidney disease, and so he doctored the symp­toms, and not the kidneys.

Thus the trouble kept growing worse, until disturbances of the water appeared, or there was gravel, or retention of the urine, or backaches — or some such plain sign of kidney trouble that there could be no doubt.

Doan’s backache kidney pills should be taken at the first sign of anything wrong. There is no other safe way, because kidney complaints are the most dangerous of all discuss, except consumption. Doan's pills are a great aid and stimulant to the kidneys. They strengthen the kidneys, and help them to perform properly that most important of all functions — the filtering of the blood, — help them to flush off, and carry away with the surplus water, all those impurities which the blood gathers up in its circuit of the body. In no other way can you be well.

This medicine has been in use by the Quakers for 72 years, and is today made of the same roots and herbs as it was 72 years ago. It cannot be improved by adding to, or taking away a single thing. Its effects are only on the kidneys and bladder — not on the bowels. This is the reason for its great success: It does one thing only, hot it done that one thing well.

Doan's backache kidney pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists for P.T. 13 per box, or P.T. 71 for 6 boxes; or they may be had by poet from the general agent foe Egypt, Mr. Max Fischer, Hotel du Nil St., Mousky St. Cairo.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: SPORT AT SUEZ The E. T. 0. cricket ground at Suez has been prepared for the coming season, and the X I is in very good form, ready to compete with any team from any man-of-war that may wish to challenge them.The first hockey season at Suez has been very successful Five matches hare been played by the E. T. C. team against teams, one from H. M. S. "Hogue,” one from H.M.S. "Barflour," and three from the cable ship "Electra." Of these matches, the E. T. C. won four and lost one. The winning team was from H. U. S. "Hogue." The football season consisted of fifteen matches. One of the most sporting Association teams at Suez consists of the pupils of the Government Schools, who are very keen on the game and show any amount of pluck. They played the E.T.C. eleven nine times, and secured four goals against seventy during the season with indomitable perseverance. A large number of football matches were arranged with the various cable ships calling at Suez, and there were also matching against H.M.S “Hogue” and Port Said. The victory of the E.T.C eleven over Port Said was more decisive, and they scored six goals to nil. Although the Port Said eleven was picked team, selected from the best players of the large English colony there, they were entirely defeated. We regret to say one of the Port Said team is still in hospital. The Suez Golf Club is very flourishing thanks to the energetic and genial secretary, Mr. Hoseason. Owing to the organizing genius of this gentleman the club has been brought up to the highest pitch of prosperity and numbers nearly half a hundred members, including all the “cream’ of the English society of Suez and Port Tewfik. There links are amongst the best in Egypt, and many patrons of the royal and Antient game aver that the Helouan links do not hold a candle of those of Suez. Two golf competitions are held every month, one bogey and one stroke, and substantial prizes are always competed for. The club unfortunately is on the point of losing one of its most enterprising members, Mr. George Owen. This prominent member of the English colony at Suez is a thorough sportsman and is most popular. He is keen member of the Golf Club committee and exerted himself greatly in the construction of the new links Mr. Owen has been appointed to the responsible position of superintended of the Eastern Telegraph Company at Bombay, and a banquet was given in his honor on Saturday. He has been the presiding genius of golf at Suez and is an all-around sportsman. A fine bowling groom has recently been laid out at the Golf Club and, this addition to the many distractions of Suez has been greatly appreciated. A large number of ladies have taken bowling, and this innocent recreation appears to attract many votaries. The Golf Club has also laid out a croquet “lawn” The word "lawn” at Suez is used in symbolical sense, as there is not a blade of grass for many miles around. The “lawn” consists of carefully rolled sand, chosen for its hard surface, and it makes an admirable ground. The Golf Club is greatly appreciated by the English colony at Suez because it forms a convenient place of assembly for local gossip of an innocent and harmless character. The two tennis clubs at Suez have lately received many new members. The two clubs are formed of the Suez and Port Tewfik residents and the members of the Eastern Telegraph Staff. Every week there are three "at homes" on the club’s grounds. A tournament is now being played between the members of the E. T. C, Club.

BRITISH TRADE WITH EGYPTA correspondent recently wrote to the President of the Board of Trade, drawing attention to the fact that, according to the latest report to hand, British commerce with Egypt showed a distinctly shrinking tendency. It was farther suggested that the Government would do well to establish some system of trustworthy inquiry in all cases where there was a falling off in trade with other countries. In reply the correspondent has been furnished with the figures for the last ten years, representing the proportion borne by imports from the United Kingdom to the total imports into Egypt as follow:1895, 31.5 per cent. ; 1896, 31.1 per cent . ; 1897, 33.4 per cent ; 1898, 35.1 per cent. ; 1899, 37.9 per cent ; 190n, 37.6 per cent ; 1901, 36.5 per cent; 1902, 36.8 per cent t. ; 1903, 35.3 percent ; 1904, 34.0 per cent It is farther pointed out that, "although the proportion of imports derived from the United Kingdom has declined slightly during the last few years, it is still greater than in the first few of the years included above."It further appears, from the official reply, “that the fluctuations in the shore figures from year to year arise, to a large extent, from the variations in the price of coal, the imports of which are derived almost entirely from the United Kingdom. If oral be excluded, the figures will appear as follow “1896, 28.1 per cent, 1896. 28.0 per cent; 1897, 30 8 per cent ; 1898, 31.4 per cent. ; 1899, 32.9 per cent ; 1900, 82.4 per cent; 1901, 82.3 per cent; 1902, 33 0 per cent. ; 1903, 31.8 per cent; 1904, 81-0 per cent

Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
